title: FortiGate Firewall Authentication Bypass - Patch Not Working

timeline.event: Fortinet releases patch and advisory for CVE-2026-59718
Security researchers report patch is ineffective
Arctic Wolf publishes detailed technical analysis
CISA adds to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog
Active exploitation confirmed in the wild

simple_summary.what_happened: A serious security bug was found in Fortinet FortiGate firewalls. Attackers can log in as admin without a password. They use a trick with login messages (called SAML) to bypass security. The bad news: even firewalls that installed the patch are still getting hacked.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Any organization using FortiGate firewalls, FortiProxy, FortiWeb, or FortiSwitchManager. You are at risk if FortiCloud SSO login is turned on. This affects FortiOS versions 7.0.x and 7.2.x.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: They send a fake login message to your firewall. Step 2: The firewall thinks they are a real admin. Step 3: They download your firewall settings and passwords. Step 4: They create new admin accounts to come back later. Step 5: They can now control your entire network.
what_you_should_do: Turn off FortiCloud SSO login right now
Check your logs for strange logins (especially from unknown IPs)
If you see suspicious logins, reset all admin passwords immediately
Block management access from the internet
Wait for the new patch and install it as soon as it's released
Review all admin accounts - delete any you don't recognize
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: This is a firewall - it protects your entire network. If attackers control your firewall, they can see all your traffic, change security rules, and enter your network whenever they want. This is like giving a burglar the keys to your house and the code to your alarm.

tactics.description: Attackers exploit the FortiGate management interface exposed to the internet
Attackers create new admin accounts to maintain access
Attackers download firewall configuration containing credentials
Attackers may modify firewall rules to allow further access

detection_guidance.summary: Focus on authentication logs, admin activity, and network connections to management interfaces. Look for SSO logins from unexpected locations.

log_sources.description: Native firewall logs showing admin authentication and configuration changes
Correlation of login events with known malicious IPs

what_to_look_for.indicator: SSO logins from external IP addresses
what_to_look_for.description: Admin logins using method='sso' from IP addresses outside your organization
Any new administrator accounts created, especially with full permissions
Configuration file downloads, especially from unusual IPs
Changes to firewall policies that allow new inbound traffic

immediate_actions.description: Go to System > Settings > Set 'Allow administrative login using FortiCloud SSO' to Off
immediate_actions.command:
config system global
set admin-forticloud-sso-login disable
end

immediate_actions.description: Restrict management interface access to internal IPs only using local-in policies
immediate_actions.command:
config system interface
edit "mgmt"
set allowaccess https ssh
set trust-ip 10.0.0.0/8 192.168.0.0/16
end

immediate_actions.description: Review all admin accounts and remove any unauthorized accounts
Change passwords for all legitimate admin accounts
Check logs for unauthorized access in the past 30 days
immediate_actions.command:
execute log filter category event
execute log filter subtype admin
execute log display
